column5: Maybe the person purchased another ring? Maybe 6' under?
Maybe the person purchased another ring? Maybe 6' under?

Someone is in a lot of trouble. I found a Mans wedding band at a camp near Ear Falls, Ontario the week of 9/1/07. If any one knows anyone who is now living out of there car and lost one please have them call me @ 224-402-3603. Thanks

In June (2005) an unfortunate fellow from Chicago lost his newly earned wedding band on the dock at Onaway. Bounced once and in the water it went. The poor fellow along with several other hearty souls in his party decided it would be a good idea to try and recover the lost jewelry by sifting the lake bottom. Bringing up as much as they could with a garbage can cover, shovel and anything else the could find. After diving into the depths time and time again, and sifting through the sand and muck for almost an hour, the poor fellow decided to give up the search and beg forgiveness. Never found it, never saw him again. Don't know whether it was the cold shoulder at home or the hypothermia from the water.....I get the chills just thinking about it. Moral of the story.....if you can get your jewelry off, DO, and leave it at home, nobody in Ontario is impressed by your gold take. That lake claimed a nice watch several years back when it got hooked on my life preserver and decided to take a swim. If you are ever down in South Inlet around the small island halfway down and hear a faint alarm at 9am, it's just my watch, never could figure out how to reset that thing.
the safest place beside back home is to wear it. it wont fall out of a pocket that way.

Did you report it to the camp? Surely the person who lost it would have contacted them by now.

My guess is that when the guy got to that beautiful water and thought about his wife at home he said... the heck with her!
